title: Ghostwalk, fundraisers for Alzheimer's and breast cancer to top spirited week
text: Ghostwalk, fundraisers for Alzheimer's and breast cancer to top spirited week Week Ahead Best Bets: Top activities for the coming week. Posted Oct. 18, 2015 at 5:23 PM Updated at 5:37 PM Posted Oct. 18, 2015 at 5:23 PM Updated at 5:37 PM Week Ahead Best Bets: Top activities for the coming week. 1. Annual New Bern ‘Ghostwalk’ The 25th annual New Bern Historical Society’s “Ghostwalk: “Un-Modern Family” will be Thursday through Saturday evenings. Times are 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. Thursday and 5:30 to 9:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday. There are ghost sites in homes, churches and businesses in New Bern’s Historic District. Advance tickets are $16, with $22 tickets on days of the event. On the web: newbernhistorical.org Call 638-8558. 2. ‘Get Your Pink On!’ The third annual New Bern “Get Your Pink On!” fundraiser will be Thursday at the Isaac Taylor Garden, 228 Craven St. There will be raffles, food, activities, guest speakers, cancer fighters and survivors, and more. It is the group’s largest fundraiser for breast cancer research and benefits local cancer patients throughout the year. Admission is free, with donations accepted. On the web: newberngetyourpinkon.com Call Thea Kincaid at 636-2628, or email thea@theasideas.com 3. Walk to End Alzheimer’s The 2015 New Bern Walk to End Alzheimer’s is scheduled for Saturday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. The site is the The Galley Stores parking lot, 300 E. Front St. On-site registration will begin at 8 a.m., with registration and pre-event activities at 10 a.m. There will be a welcome ceremony at 11 a.m. and a Promise Garden ceremony. The walk will begin at 11:45 a.m., with 12:15 p.m. team and individual fundraiser announcements, along with a raffle drawing. Call 919-803-8285 or email jbriand@alz.org On the web: act.alz.org 4. ‘Evening at the Cabaret’ An “Evening at the Cabaret” is scheduled for Friday at the North Carolina History Center, 529 S. Front St., New Bern. It will be from 6 to 10 p.m. It will feature renowned singer, pianist and entertainer Benjy Templeton, with dinner catered by The Flame. The proceeds will benefit Coastal Coalition for Substance Abuse Prevention’s efforts to create communities free of substance abuse by preventing underage drinking and reducing prescription misuse and abuse. Admission is $60. Tickets will be available on the web: ccsap.ticketleap.com/cabaret-evening/ Ticket can be purchased at Mitchell Hardware, 215 Craven St. Call 649-1615. Here are other events that should be on your radar: Page 2 of 4 - ■ The New Bern-Craven County Public Library has a number of events this week, beginning with the Young Adults, ninth to 12th grade Monday at 4:30 p.m. It will include a costuming workshop. At 2:30 p.m., there will be an intermediate internet class. On Tuesday, the sixth- to eighth-grade group will meet at 4:30 p.m. for a puppetry workshop. At 6:30 p.m., there will be a basic sign language class. On Wednesday, it is time for a Lunch ‘n Learn: East Smart, Move More, Weigh Less class at noon. Also Wednesday, there will be a 2:30 p.m. Windows 10 class and Children’s Movie Day at 4 p.m., for grades kindergarten to fifth. This month’s movie is about a young bear traveling to London in search of his home. The Brown family finds him in Paddington Station and takes him home. On Sunday, the Friends of the Library will present author and historian Kevin Duffus, with his latest research on the pirate Blackbeard. “What’s Wrong With Blackbeard?” will be at 3 p.m. ■ Auditions for soloists for the 33rd performance of G.F. Handel’s “Messiah” will be held on Monday. The tryouts are from 7 to 8 p.m. in the Choir Room of Centenary United Methodist Church, 309 New St., New Bern. Soloists should prepared to sing from the musical. To reserve an audition time, call Pat Rowlett at 637-3270. Performances are scheduled for Dec. 14. ■ The Craven County Fair will open Thursday at the Craven Fairgrounds on U.S. 70 East and continue through Nov. 1 There is a $5 gate admission and $20 armbands are sold daily, good for the entire day. The fair will open at 6 p.m. Monday through Friday; 11 a.m. on Saturdays and 1 p.m. on Sundays. It will feature amusement rides, vendors and live entertainment, including Trainwreck on Friday and David Lee Jones on Oct. 30. The West Edgecombe Mini-Pullers are on tap Saturday and Bobby Brantley and “Crazy Dave” from the TV series “Lizard Lick” will perform Oct. 31. Call 636-0303. On the web: cravencountyfair.com ■ A Screening of Glen Campbell’s Documentary, “I’ll be Me” regarding Alzheimer’s disease will be Thursday at Craven Community College. Registration is at 4 p.m. The event will be in Orringer Auditorium, 800 College Court. Tickets are $5. RSVP to Jennifer Briand at 919-951-8725. On the web: alz.org ■ The Friday night “Juice” at Galley Store, 300 E. Front St., New Bern, will be this week from 5 to 7 p.m. Page 3 of 4 - It will feature wines and craft beers, along with gourmet appetizers. The tasting is free, with appetizers $5. Call 633-4648. ■ The weekly Cedar Grove Cemetery Tours are each Saturday at 4 p.m. Visitors meet at the gate on Queen Street. The Earl of Craven Questers Chapter conducts the tour, which feature information about the “residents” of Cedar Grove. Tours are factually based and entertaining. Admission is $10. Questers is an international organization dedicated to historic preservation. Craven County’s local chapter has 21 members and raises funds to underwrite the preservation and restoration of the cemetery. Tickets may be purchased at the New Bern Historical Society, 511 Broad St., or at the gate. Call 638-8558. ■“All Hallow’s Eve” will be Saturday at Tryon Palace from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. It will feature ghouls, ghosts, witches, crafts, games, stories and candy. Children are welcome to dress in costume. While wandering the haunted grounds, visitors will encounter friendly ghosts like Thadeus Thorton Helpit the blacksmith; Lady Katherine the highwayman; Lucretia Crookshank; and Mistress Penelope, the not-so-wicked witch. It is designed for ages 12 and under and is free for children dressed in Halloween costumes. Tickets are $4 for ages 13 to 18; $10 for adults; and free for members of the Tryon Palace Foundation. Call 639-3500. On the web: tryonpalace.org ■ The Old Theater’s eighth annual Chili Cookoff will be Saturday from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. in Oriental. Each chef provides at least five gallons of chili for sample on the grounds of the Oriental Marina, 103 Wall St. The event is held for fun and to raise funds for the Old Theater. Contact Nelda Coats at 639-1616, email to neldacoats@gmail.com; or call Ellyn Speciale at 571-1324 or email to gustogertie@gmail.com. ■ The Down East FolkArts Society will present Suzie Vinnick in concert Friday at 6:30 p.m. at Trent River Coffee Company, 208 Craven St., New Bern. The doors open at 6 p.m. and the music is at 7:30 p.m. Vinnick brings a gorgeous voice, described by organizers as being “spun of gold,” including the blues or a ballad. She performs blues, folk, country and pop. General admission is $15, with military and society members admitted for $12. Tickets are $8 for full-time students. Tickets are available via PayPal on the web: downeastfolkarts.org or by calling or texting 646-4657 for reservations. In New Bern, tickets will be available at Trent River Coffee Company or at Bank of the Arts, 317 Middle St. Page 4 of 4 - Call 633-6444 or email folkartsenc@gmail.com ■ The “At the Gallery Concert: Burton Lane” will be performed by John Van Dyke and Tim Maddox on Saturday at the Bank of the Arts, 317 Middle St., New Bern. It will begin at 7 p.m. It will feature the music of Burton Lane, known for his Broadway musicals. He wrote songs such as “How are Things in Glocca Morra” and “Old Devil Moon.” He served as president of the American Guild of Authors and Composers and on the board of directors for the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. In addition to his many accolades, he is credited with discovering Francis Gumm, who would later be known as Judy Garland. Tickets for Craven Arts Council Members are $15 plus tax and $20 plus tax for non-members. Call 638-2577.
